title: 114_hr1533
content: The "Medical Device Tax Elimination Act" repeals the medical device excise tax by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This Act applies to sales after its enactment date and includes limitations on deductions related to oil, natural gas, or primary products. The amendment prohibits major integrated oil companies from deducting gross receipts from oil, gas, or primary product production. Effective for taxable years after December 31, 2014. The amendment prohibits major integrated oil companies from using a specific inventory method. Effective for taxable years after December 31, 2014. The amendment requires adjustments to be made with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury. The net amount of adjustments under section 481 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 must be spread out over a period not exceeding 8 taxable years. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR MAJOR INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES WHO ARE DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for major integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such taxpayers will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code includes special rules for major integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. These taxpayers pay amounts to foreign countries or possessions, which are not considered taxes under specific conditions. A dual capacity taxpayer is defined as a person who meets certain criteria in relation to a foreign country or possession of the United States. The Internal Revenue Code has special rules for dual capacity taxpayers, who pay amounts to foreign countries or possessions. A dual capacity taxpayer is defined as a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession and receives a specific economic benefit from it. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to income taxes imposed under the laws of a foreign country on income derived from business activities within that country. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid after December 31, 2014, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States.
